passages.text: Public Sector Fiscal Deficit Widens to \(7.9\%\) of GDP; Gross Public Debt Rises to \(77.6\%\) of GDP

Bottom Line: The consolidated public sector recorded a larger than expected \(R\) 66.6bn deficit in Jul. On a 12- month rolling basis, the consolidated public sector is a \(0.2\%\) of GDP primary fiscal deficit, which we expect to more than double by year- end. The overall public sector fiscal deficit (primary surplus minus net interest payments) is tracking at a high \(79\%\) of GDP. The stock of gross general government debt as a share of GDP is tracking at \(77.6\%\) ( \(+100\) bp from June; \(89.9\%\) of GDP according to the IMF standard definition) and is expected to continue to climb. A pro- cyclical fiscal stance and the reluctance to control spending severely undermined the credibility of the fiscal targets and contributed to an over- heated economy. Furthermore, a weak and unreliable fiscal anchor increased fiscal risk- premia, leading to unanchored short- and medium- term inflation expectations.

We expect the consolidated public sector primary balance to remain in the red for the foreseeable future, and the gross debt dynamics to remain on an upward trend in the coming years. Placing the debt dynamics on a structural sustained declining trend and building fiscal buffers remain key macro challenges. That would require structural primary fiscal surpluses above \(2\%\) of GDP, which would contribute to lowering the neutral real interest rate. Such an outcome is highly unlikely in the near term, in our view.

1. The consolidated public sector posted a large R\(66.6bn deficit in Jul, worse than the market consensus and the R\)21.3bn deficit a year ago. The central government recorded a R\)56.4bn deficit and the states and municipalities a R\(8.1bn deficit. The state-owned enterprises, in turn, posted a large R\)2.1bn deficit. Part of the large July central government deficit reflects court-ordered payments (precatórios).
2. On a 12-month rolling basis, the consolidated public sector recorded a \(0.22\%\) of GDP primary fiscal deficit; with the states and municipalities running a R\)16.2bn surplus (+0.13% of GDP).
3. On a 12-month rolling basis, the overall public sector fiscal deficit (primary surplus minus net interest payments) is tracking at \(7.9\%\) of GDP, with the net
interest bill at \(7.6\%\) of GDP (broadly unchanged from a year ago).

4. The stock of gross general government debt rose 100bp to \(77.6\%\) of GDP (up from \(71.7\%\) at end-22) [89.9% of GDP according to the IMF standard definition which includes central bank holdings of freely usable government debt instruments]. The stock of net public sector debt rose 80bp to \(63.7\%\) of GDP (56.1% of GDP at end-22).

The central bank will publish the Quarterly Inflation Report (QIR) on August 29. The 2Q25- QIR will contain updated forecasts for growth and headline/core inflation over the relevant horizon for monetary policy.

Furthermore, in the 2Q25- QIR the central bank is likely to update the overall growth- inflation balance of risks (though likely not the forward guidance) vis- a- vis the Aug 7 MPC meeting policy statement given that for the QIR, the central bank has a larger set of data than it did when the MPC last met: 1H Aug inflation and the real GDP \(2^{\mathrm{nd}}\) vintage print.

On inflation, we expect the central bank to repeat the Aug 7 MPC meeting forecasts: end- 2025 headline/core inflation at \(3.7\% /3.7\%\) (up from \(3.3\% /3.4\%\) in the previous QIR), with convergence to the \(3.0\%\) target still expected for 3Q2026.

On growth, in the 1Q25- QIR the 2025 real GDP growth forecast was between \(- 0.5\%\) and \(+0.7\%\) (midpoint \(0.1\%\) ) and for 2026 between \(0.1\%\) and \(1.7\%\) (midpoint \(0.9\%\) ). We expect the central bank to revise the 2025 growth forecast upward; the \(- 0.5\%\) lower- limit for growth in 2025 is now too pessimistic given the recent real activity dynamics and outlook for US import tariffs.

In order to calibrate the monetary policy path, we will pay particular attention to the characterization of the balance of risks to inflation and growth, and the list and ranking order of both upside and downside risks to inflation and growth.

We will also pay attention to the revised forecast for the output gap and labor market slack estimates. A less tight goods market and easing labor pressures would add policy room to extend the easing cycle.
Bank Lending (Jul); bank credit decelerated to \(5.2\%\) yoy in real terms in Jun (vs \(7.3\%\) yoy in May).

In real terms, consumer lending expanded \(8.9\%\) yoy ( \(0.3\%\) mom sa) in Jun, vs. \(8.8\%\) yoy ( \(0.4\%\) mom sa) in May. Corporate credit softened: \(5.4\%\) yoy (- 1.2% mom sa), vs. \(9.2\%\) yoy ( \(0.8\%\) mom sa) in May.
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
LA-IT5 Policy Rate Simple Average

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
